												Background:Purchased as part of a bundle from Bundle Stars. I played the first two games in the series to death back when they came out.Impressions:Commandos stands tall among action strategy games. It was a simple formula: a set of men are dropped into a mission, each with a certain set of skills and using them in concert you dismantle the enemies defences and confound their long term goals.While the games does lean heavily on the two most useful characters (Tiny and the Spy) the situations force you to think creatively and apart from a few small instances you are completely free to tackle the mission as you see fit.It's almost bewildering that no game has successfully recaptured the formula since, even the successive games in the franchises have failed to really improve or even live up to this classic piece of strategy.Each mission can take minutes or even several hours to complete on your first run through and while the Merit system on completion gives you a score (based on damage taken, damage done and speed of completion) you can be drawn back to try and complete the mission quicker and more cleverly there is ultimately no reward for doing so.. other than your own satisfaction.The biggest issue is that the Steam version of the game installs poorly and in an almost unusable state. the game runs impossibly fast on modern PCs, the config file is missing the line to allow saving, multicore PCs will make the game unstable and widescreen monitors have black bands at the boarders. thankfully all these can be fixed and I've collated all the fixes I used on the Commandos wikia as noted below.Fixes:See the page on the 'Commandos Wikia' for 'Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines Fixes'.http://commandos.wikia.com/wiki/Fixing_CommandosThe Good:*A classic formula that stands up today for it's simplicity and functions.*Missions can be tackled many ways.*The settings have a historical context and introduced as such.*Missions are diverse.*Fast save/load system makes experimentation less frustrating than you'd think.*Huge sense of triumph from executing a plan that takes out even a single awkward guard.*Looks pretty good considering it's age.The Bad:*Terrible install from Steam that makes the game unplayable without some searching and tweaking.*Merit is heavily determined by speed which I don't find fun.*The leveling mechanic 'Merit' never had a function originally nor now.*Vehicles are overpowered but also limited.*A few missions have an element that only has one solution...*Leading to some missions having to be restarted unless you keep lots of saves.Recommended for: War, Action and isometric strategy fans.Conclusion.9/10. Once the screen, stability and speed issues are fixed it's a huge blast.

Short version: 87%Commandos is one of the greatest classics of squad-based tactical combat games, where you command a group of elite soldiers through twenty maps of sabotage in semi-realistic World War II scenarios. The map and control design were so well made that this game still shines as bright as it did in 1998.Long version:Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines combines isometric tactical combat with real-time strategy and stealth. This mixture works so perfectly that it is still remembered by many to this date not just as a beloved childhood game, but as something revolutionary.And Commandos achieved this without any real plot. All twenty maps are more or less based on real WWII events, but they don’t have much story other than a historical introduction piece and a short mission briefing. No underlying plot, no character drama, just meticulously designed levels with several objectives.Achieving these goals usually requires careful planning, lots of sneaking around, and diversion tactics. Enemy guards are placed in strategic ways, and getting discovered or leaving a body in the open results in an alarm, which usually leads to mission failure.To finish the task, the player gets control over six commandos, all with distinct, unique abilities. Sadly, all but two of them are useless for almost anything apart from one certain task (driving the getaway car, rowing the boat, and so on), since only they can move dead bodies out of the way – something that is crucial on all levels. All the others usually just camp in one safe corner of the map, unused for most of the mission.The game was well-received and spawned an entire franchise, which in retrospect made Behind Enemy Lines the one with the shortest and easiest levels, but also with the biggest variety. It’s not as difficult as Beyond the Call of Duty, as complex as Men of Courage, or as action-oriented as Destination: Berlin, but still retains most of its old charm.

A real-time tactics game consisting of 20 missions with a lot of wonks and bonks in design but overall satisfying to play.You use a team of commandos, numbers vary by mission, to perform assigned objectives then exit the area. It's relatively like a puzzle game where you'll have to time certain tasks right and use an appropriate commando in an appropriate situation. For the most part you'll be using one commando more than the rest however everyone does play a vital role and in order to finish a mission as "cleanly" as possible everyone will be required to fulfill their roles in each mission.A real cool feature this game has is the ability to have multiple (I think a maximum of 8 total) windows in the game and a function that lets the camera for the selected window to follow an enemy or commando.The game requires quite a bit of thinking and even though you've got the enemy's movements down and you know your way around you'll still need a lot of patience to get through a mission without causing too much or no fuss. Each mission also gets much, much lengthier as you progress (after I think mission 15/20 it takes me around 3 or more hours to complete).It will be very helpful to learn the shortcut keys for each commando (as opposed to always clicking on their items) for better convenience and quicker actions in given situations. Unfortunately the keys are un-rebindable so memorizing the keys may be a bit more of a hassle.The AI, whether the Nazis or your commandos, can be pretty dumb. The commandos will have a habit of spazzing out or maybe taking some weird extra 2-foot diagonal path or whatever when maybe all you wanted them to do is walk along the wall whilst hugging it and turn on the next corner while still hugging said wall. The Nazis, especially the ones in groups, may glitch up a bit when making a turn on their paths meaning their field of visions have a good chance of going all over the place.With an isometric game like this I figured you should at least be able to see or go "behind" large structures especially since the enemy can do it, but you can't. If you click on a building thinking you'll go "behind" it then the assigned commando will most likely try to find the fastest route "in front" of it. It's also a pain every now and again to try and put one commando where another is specifically located because there's no option to click through your guys so you may accidentally click on your guy instead of moving one there.Really it's a cool game and despite all its design flaws it feels good to get through a really tough and lengthy mission.

												I originally played this game in what seemed like a different life; back in 1998 when it came out. I remember spending countless hours playing this game, and I remember it being incredibly difficult but loads of fun. It is very reminiscent of other strategy games of the mid-late nineties, but set in World War II. You command a group of commandos, all with different skills and abilities. Each stage has different line-ups of soldiers and usually a different inventory. The spy can disguise himself as a Nazi captain, the Marine can dive underwater and commandeer an inflatable raft, the driver can control tanks, the sapper can place bombs and traps, etc. Some characters run faster, and only some characters can heal. I will say, if you are looking for an easy play through and/or get easily frustrated, this game is NOT for you. It is very challenging and you die almost immediately if you are caught. You will find yourself constantly saving and loading, and I found it not uncommon to save/load around fifty times a map. It is stealth based and you will die if you go in guns blazing. Don't let this discourage you though, since it's a very fun game and gave me countless hours of entertainment. When I bought this game here on Steam it was something stupid-cheap like 75 cents. Even if you only play a map or two, you get your money's worth to at least give it a try. It is of course heavily dated (I almost laughed when I saw the system requirements), but the value and fun is there. Give it a shot, you won't regret it.

												I do not know if this game was unique in its concept at the time, but it's must certainly one of the few puzzle strategy games out there. I've not seen many like it. Only the Desperado games, set in the Wild West, as far as I know.Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines follows bunch of special missions in WWII where you as an officer use the skills of a couple specialised commandos, specially trained British soldiers. Each commando has his own set of tools to help you to complete each mission. And it's up to you to decide when and how to utilise each commando to overcome certain obstacles. If any of your commandos dies, you'll fail the mission. You'll have to pay attention not to alert any of the German soldiers or officers, as they're always alert and on the lookout. They watch and listen to anything suspicious. Some garrison buildings with the swastika flying will contain soldiers that will come out and patrol when the alarm is sounded. This will make your missions far more difficult, so stealth is key. Each new mission is an ever bigger puzzle you have to try to complete. You have 20 to complete.The game has, despite being from 1998 and sometimes in need of workarounds to get it working properly, a great atmosphere, supported by actual WWII film footage and little background stories, and a unique aesthetic.

												Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines is absolutely brilliant for a game made in 1998, its jammed pack with strategic depth while still maintains a reasonable difficulty level. In Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines, instead of controlling massive armies, you control six specialized units. The map is designed in such a way that makes all your units have synergy with each other. While you can win early games with very little use of decoys, stealing, and stealth, the end game requires your mastery of all your units’ abilities. This game is as perfect a strategy game as chess. Like chess you see the battlefield with no fog of war, there is no resource management, and none of the numerical/economic factors that limit the pure strategy/tactics of the game. The only fault I can even find on Commandos: Behind Enemy Lines is its severe lack of sound, voice, and ambience.

												Commandos is yet another game, whose beauty lies in its crazy difficulty. While it is refered to as a "strategy", I would rather describe it as "WW2-themed logical game / isometric view sneaker / (seldom) tight-timed action click-fest".The men, you control are more rookies than experts. They are outnumbered, outgeared and underqualified. Only one of the commandos can use an assult rifle (at the distance of approx 20 in-game meters/yards). Their effective range of pistol shot is half that number. The enemies shoot accurately from further distances and can easily kill all of the squad within a few seconds. Only two of them are stong enough to carry dead bodies. If you can turn a dead eye to these dumb assumptions, you will get an extremely challenging and still fun game. The team must resort to stealth moves and silent kills, at least until they bring down enough enemies and neutralize their adantage of numbers. Most of the time the player must analyse the patrolling routes of enemy soliders and look for weak spots. Then plan and execute a quick action of taking the prey down without alerting remaining guards. This is the point, when precise clicking comes into play. The game sometimes leaves no more then a few seconds to get nearby unnoticed, point a solider, kill him (click), grab his corpse (click), move to safe place (point and click) before another guy turns around and sees you over the body of his fellow. He usually does so. Then you need to improve the plan, create extra diversion or just wait for a better timing. There is a lot of loading after failed attempts. The game allows to quick save and quick load with ctrl+S / ctrl+L respectively. Use them a lot and always have a backup save at the beginning of the mission. There is no auto-save of the career progress. Past the fifth mission the game becomes quite difficult, the missions are large, enemies numerous and they observation areas overlap a lot. The game consists of 20 regular missions and six short trainings. The playtime per mission is approximately 1h past mission 1, 2-3h in mid game and 3-4h at the end. The game also offers a score of the mission depending on the time and damage taken, but I didn't personally feel compelled to master every single level.Technical:* The game runs in the maximum resolution of 1024 x 768, which is rather poor now,* there is no ingame music during the missions (that's not a bug)* I noticed sound issues during the debriefing (that is a bug),* The game sometimes asks you to insert a game cd into the drive. Chosing a random option "retry" or "cancel" should let you through, but I would rather see it fixed,Conclusion:* Commandos are beyond straightforward classification* high difficulty level, lots of save+loads, * very challanging and rewarding, but can also be frustrating for impatient players* a bit outdated graphics, unsuited for contemporary displays* poor and annoying sounds, can be muded* at least 40 hours to beat* minor porting issues* no achievivments, medicore replayablityDo not play, if you* do not like hybrids* do not like to die / reload* do not like to get stuck for 15 minutes wandring how to kill that guy, only to see twenty more soliders to hunt down Do play if, you* love to hunt for a weak spots* prefer silent killing to gun-blazing* experiment, plan, try, fail, improve, execute, succeed* don't mind outdated graphics and sound

The difficulty lies in having to observe the conditions of the mission (ground, guards, patrols) before acting i do not like crazy, but sometimes also boldness is rewarded. You must learn to use your resources and usually find several possible ways of dealing with each assignment.After playing it again, you realize it has lost none of the gameplay that characterized and has aged surprisingly well. The level of difficulty of the missions is perfectly structured, from a first mission is essentially a tutorial to the last this goes up gradually without big jumps. This increase is offset by the acquired skill in handling the characters through the game.The weakest aspects of the game are in the low use of some of the characters to be very limited by their roles, being used on a mission only in a particular action, but having to take in all the action while avoiding being killed.Undoubtedly the worst of the game is in multiplayer. Played in cooperative mode, having to wait for each player to the other end their movement. You also can not use the same character for more than one player, resulting in a frustrating gaming experience.In short: Commandos is an excellent game that will satisfy the discerning player who does not like the easy challenges. Its gameplay is single player, multiplayer being their weak point.
